Award.AwardTitle: Xavier University Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program 2012-2017

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Xavier University's Robert Noyce Scholarship Program is focusing on attracting community service-oriented science, computer science, and mathematics students to careers in high school teaching. Xavier is creating opportunities, including tutoring and summer internships, for science, computer science, and mathematics majors to teach science, technology and mathematics content to underserved, urban students. It is also enhancing Xavier's education program by revising the required introductory education course to incorporate theories related to asset-based community development including experiential learning and neighborhood tours. Xavier's Noyce program is providing three points of entry to accommodate varying decision-making processes: the beginning of students' junior or senior year or in their first year after graduation. Fifteen undergraduate science, computer science, and mathematics majors are being awarded $20,000 scholarships for two years and eight graduate students are receiving $20,000 stipends for one full-time year of licensure courses. The project is investigating how service experiences can encourage science, computer science, and mathematics majors to consider teaching, and whether students who are attracted to teaching because of a personal commitment to service are more likely to be successful in high-need districts and stay in these school environments for longer periods. It is also considering what curricular supports make education licensure courses and field work relevant to students motivated by a commitment to community engagement, and what supports enable new science, computer science, and mathematics teachers to be successful in high needs districts. By 2017, the program will have increased the number of Xavier students attaining science, computer science, and mathematics teaching licensure by 52%, helping to address critical shortages of teachers of these subjects in Ohio and Kentucky.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The initial focus of this project was to provide further investigation and assessment of motivations for STEM students pursuing teaching, particularly those who are interested in working in high-need districts. We sought to verify linkages between the desire to teach and a passion for making a difference or contributing to society. Xavier's program investigated how service experiences, such as tutoring, can encourage STEM majors to consider teaching, and whether students were attracted to teaching because of a personal commitment to service. 

 

During the life of the grant, we at Xavier have instituted one-on-one tutoring (with an emphasis on assisting students in STEM areas) for underserved students in the surrounding community and developed and maintained relationships with various community partners. Our students were actively involved in outreach programs conducted with those partners. We have also successfully instituted Xavier-run STEM camps where our interns and future scholars acted as the teachers, counselors and mentors for students throughout the greater Cincinnati area. We have also created Saturday enrichment events run throughout the year for students in Cincinnati public schools with a focus on STEM activities that engage them in hands-on learning.

 

Overall, this project has had significant intellectual merit and broader impacts. We have addressed the shortage of mathematics and science teachers at the secondary level in that we have had 15 STEM majors, and participants of the Xavier Noyce Project go on to choose teaching STEM as a career.

 

The program successfully created summer internships for STEM majors that provide opportunities to teach underserved children. The recruitment and scholarship selection process did achieve the goal of attracting diversity in the program, by attracting persons from diverse backgrounds and generally underrepresented in STEM teaching. Xavier created a website to market the Noyce program and

STEM awareness. Our faculty and investigators have attended and presented at various professional meetings and conferences. We anticipate publication in a relevant journal based on data collected throughout the grant period.
